name: Geometrization conjecture
rephrased: Every 'nice' three-dimensional topological space can be broken down into simpler pieces, each having one of eight possible standard geometric structures (like spheres or hyperbolic spaces).
implication_form: If a three-dimensional topological space (satisfying certain conditions) is given, then it can be decomposed into geometric pieces, each conforming to one of eight model geometries.
explained: Thurston's geometrization conjecture states that every compact, connected, three-dimensional manifold can be decomposed, or cut apart, along spherical two-dimensional surfaces into a finite number of pieces. Each resulting piece should then be one of exactly eight so-called 'Thurston geometries'. These eight geometries are: the spherical geometry (S3), the Euclidean geometry (E3), the hyperbolic geometry (H3), and five others: the geometries S2×R, H2×R, Sol, and Nil. This decomposition essentially means that any such three-dimensional shape can be described by patching together pieces of these specific geometric structures.
